nodes.text: Heh, this section is labeled "Disbarred Bards."
I guess no one wants to admit that there might be Rogues here at the school.

options.text: Study Beginner's Lock - a Guide to Picking Locks

nodes.text: Beginner's Lock - a Guide to Picking Locks. Well, that's straightforward enough.
I think that was the name of the book we're supposed to read for class.
There's something odd about the cover of this book... it's thicker than a normal book.
It looks like it can be opened up if I pull this corner...
What do you know? There's a set of wooden lockpicks stuck in the cover!
I'll just remove them for safe keeping.
Maybe I should put the wooden lockpicks back in the book where I found them for someone else who needs them?
Maybe I should put the wooden lockpicks back in the book where I found them for someone else who needs them?
So that's how Lockpicks work!
I'll have to remember to read this book later.
Okay, I learned a little from re-reading the book, but now I need to practice picking a few locks.
I didn't notice this book before - Unlocking Your Pick Potential.
It's about lockpick tools and how to use them. Sounds useful.
Okay, not a lot of new stuff in this book, but it does show a better way to hold the picks while working on a tough lock.
I'll have to remember to read this book later.
I think I've got the theory down. Now I need to go put it into practice!
Advanced Tool Use Tips? How have I never noticed this here before?
Since we covered this a bit in class, I should be able to understand it enough to study it.

Who knew that there were so many different types of locks? Hardy, Drew, Columbo... It's hard to keep them all straight. However, the Houdini 42 turns out to be the crucial tool for opening any advanced lock.
Either that, or the Houdini Company wrote this book.

nodes.name: Lock Lore
nodes.description: I read the book, Advanced Tool Use Tips today. Bleh. It listed nine types of locks and they all needed slightly different techniques to open each one. Worse... the advanced ones all take the Houdini 42 to open them. I'm going to have to do a lot of practice if I want to get good at picking locks.

nodes.text: I'll have to remember to read this book later.
I think I've got the theory down. Now I need to go put it into practice!
Let's see... what have we here?
Interesting... hiding is as important as being quiet to the art of the stealth.
I should take my time to look around more before I start sneaking.
This book should help me understand how to use the Trap Tapper a bit more.

So I should focus on common letters when trying to solve a trap - and if the Trap Tapper still shows a letter on the wheel after I've placed it in the word, it must be somewhere else in the word as well.
Oh, this is handy! A list of the most common letters! "ETAOINSHRDLU"
I'll have to remember to read this book later.
Hmm... I like the idea of outsmarting the trap by figuring out the sorts of words the trap setter might use. It's really appropriate when I know that the Master is setting the traps around here.
I think I've learned all the Tricks of the Trap that I can from this book. I just need to go try it out.

options.text: Read "Tricksters and other Roguish Heroes in Modern Society'

nodes.text: Funny how I never noticed this book on Tricksters before now.
Who know that Tricksters are so important to our society?
I guess I should have read this one for my report in class.
This would have been a good one to read for the Trickster report.
There's a lot to learn about being a successful Disbarred Bard.
The Encyclopædia of Tool Use Techniques, Vol II: 'Advanced Jiggling' to 'Bingepicking.' There's so much to learn... and I have so little patience for any of it.
Ermagherd! This book tells you how to get into any guild you want, just by namedropping... and that it's not what you know, it's who you know! It's called Guild By Association.
Oh, wow! This book tells you how to get into any guild you want, just by namedropping... and that it's not what you know, it's who you know! It's called Guild By Association!
I never knew there was such a thing: Lockpicking Etiquette. Apparently you can pick locks, and you can pick your friends, but you're never supposed to pick your friends' locks.
(shrug) It's not like I really need them now.
Eh, you never know when you might need a spare set of lockpicks for emergencies.
